For those who intend on building this style furnace, do yourself a favor and have a paintbrush with some water nearby. You should have lined the internal wall with wire mesh before applying that cement/mortar mix.
As is, that stuff will eventually just flake off after putting it through extreme heat.
When you use wire mesh, it acts as a flexible scaffolding to make it so the cement wont break off when it is put under stress.
Same reason they use wire mesh in construction. Without it, the cement will crack and break up over time

Just an FYI, if you want fire bricks cheap/free... find a ceramic factory or grinding wheel factory. Kilns are rebuilt every so often along with kiln cars. The bricks are past their use for industrial usage, but are so large that cutting them down for craft use is very possible! Just be aware that many industrial kilns use a form of fiberfrax, unlike kaowool.

Little tip for making the Wool in the lid last longer is to seal it with a moderate (1/8-3/16" thick) coat of Satanite (refractory clay) as well as the walls of the foundry and anywhere you've drilled a hole. then it'll be pretty well bullet proof.
P.S. Satanite is a refractory clay commonly used by blacksmiths for anything from sealing the walls on a gas forge to differential hardening (setting a hamon line) on knives.
